ControlledConcept.gml:description: Particle is defined as a "General term, used without restriction as to shape composition or internal structure, for a separable or distinct unit in a [compound material]." (Neuendorf et al, 2005). Unclassified solid constituent in a compound material. Note that the term particle has no size denotation as used here. Source: Neuendorf et al 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:solid_constituent_particle
ControlledConcept.name: Solid constituent particle

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Solid constituent in a compound earth material (sense of NADMC1) that is a pre-existing object before incorporation into a particulate aggregate. "...a component of solid material that has the form of grains, clasts, fragments, or whole objects of any size, shape, composition, texture, and structure." (NADMSC SLTTs, 2004) Source: NADM SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:granular_particle
ControlledConcept.name: Granular particle

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An individual constituent, grain or fragment of a sediment or rock, produced by erosion of a larger rock mass. Particle whose origin as a fragment is a result of surface (sedimentary, weathering...) processes. 'Crystals, crystal fragments, glass and rock fragments that have been liberated from any type of pre-existing consolidated rock (volcanic or non-volcanic) by weathering or erosion and transported from the site of origin by gravity, air, water, or ice' [Schmid, 1981]. Distinguished from intraclast in that epiclast is derived from a pre-existing rock from outside the basin of deposition (NADM SLTTs 2004) before introduction into a CompoundMaterial (sense of NADMC1, 2004). Source: Schmid 1981
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:epiclast
ControlledConcept.name: Epiclast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A clast derived by erosion from older, pre-existing rock materials of any kind, usually beyond the basin of accumulation but occasionally from within the basin of deposition (as from a submarine or subaqueous exposure adjacent to a depositional site). A clast that is identified as a piece of rock. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:lithic_clast
ControlledConcept.name: Lithic clast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: "A mechanically formed and deposited fragment of a carbonate rock...derived from an older, lithified limestone or dolomite within, adjacent to, or outside the depositional site" Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005, p. 375
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:lithoclast
ControlledConcept.name: Lithoclast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An epiclast that is composed of a single mineral. Source: NADM SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:mineral_clast
ControlledConcept.name: Mineral clast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: "An individual particle ejected during a volcanic eruption." (Jackson, 1997, p. 521). Clast whose origin is a direct result of volcanic process (excludes fragments in lava autobreccia) and has not been reworked by sedimentary processes (Gillespie and Styles 1999). Source: NADM SLTTs 2004; Jackson, 1997; Gillespie and Styles 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:pyroclast
ControlledConcept.name: Pyroclast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fragment of rock generated by disruption as a direct result of volcanic action but not formed by previous activity of the magmatic system; generally derived from subvolcanic basement. Source: Gillespie and Styles 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:accidental_pyroclastic_fragment
ControlledConcept.name: Accidental pyroclastic fragment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Pyroclast that has a a rounded, fluidal shape indicating that it was in a wholly or partly molten state during formation and subsequent transport. Concept corresponds to bomb, but with no size denotation. Source: Base on Gillespie and Styles, 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:fluidal_pyroclast
ControlledConcept.name: Fluidal pyroclast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Pyroclast consisting of rock which formed during earlier (related) volcanic activity that have been ejected with other pyroclastic debris during a later eruption. Source: Base on Gillespie and Styles, 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:cognate_fragments
ControlledConcept.name: Cognate fragments

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A fragment of a crystal interpreted to have been broken by pyroclastic processes. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:crystal_fragment
ControlledConcept.name: Crystal fragment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Juvenile pyroclastic fragment formed by magma-water interaction during subaqueous or subglacial extrusion; typically consist of chilled glass. Source: Gillespie and Styles 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:hydroclast
ControlledConcept.name: Hydroclast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fragment formed directly from cooling magma during transport prior to primary deposition. Source: Gillespie and Styles 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:juvenile_pyroclastic_fragment
ControlledConcept.name: Juvenile pyroclastic fragment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: a vitric fragment in pyroclastic rocks, often with a characteristically curved surface of fracture. Shards generally consist of bubble-wall fragments produced by disintegration of pumice during or after an eruption Source: GGIPAC
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:shard
ControlledConcept.name: Shard

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A granular particle that has been shaped, worn, faceted, cut or polished by the action of windblown sand. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:ventrifact
ControlledConcept.name: Ventrifact

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A broad, general term introduced by Folk (1959, p. 4) for a component of limestone, representing a torn-up and re-worked fragment of a penecontemporaneous sediment (usually weakly consolidated) that has been eroded within the basin of deposition...and re-deposited there...The fragment may range in size from fine sand to gravel... Source: NADM SLTTs 2004; Neuendorf et al., 2005; Folk, 1959
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:intraclast
ControlledConcept.name: Intraclast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fragment formed as a direct result of volcanic activity and reworked by sedimentary processes. Source: Gillespie and Styles 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:reworked_pyroclastic_fragment
ControlledConcept.name: Reworked pyroclastic fragment

ControlledConcept.gml:description: "A type of granular particle formed by the physiological activities of organisms (plants, animals, protozoa) that produce body parts which subsequently are incorporated into a sediment aggregate. Contrast with nonbiogenic particle. Includes biogenic objects that are whole or fragmentary (bioclasts); can be fossilized or non-fossilized" Source: NADM SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:biogenic_particle
ControlledConcept.name: Biogenic particle

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Granular sedimentary particle that is a "fragmentary piece of a shell, bone, or other hard skeletal structure of an animal, plant, or protozoan. May be fossilized or non-fossilized". Use in situations where fossil organism can not be identified, thus 'material fossil' is inappropriate. Source: NADM SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:bioclast
ControlledConcept.name: Bioclast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The fossilised excrement of vertebrate animals Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:coprolite
ControlledConcept.name: Coprolite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: The preserved remains or replaced remains (casts) of plants and animals. A fossil type may have one or more described associated organisms. If particle type is materialFossil, an additional type property element may provide a reference to a Paleontologic description of the fossil. Source: GeoSciML v2 RC1 model element scope note
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:material_fossil
ControlledConcept.name: Material fossil

ControlledConcept.gml:description: "A general term for a grain that has coats or layers of foreign material, usually fine mud-sized and occasionally recrystallized, that form concentric or overlapping shells around a core of rock, shell, peloidal, or intraclastic material." (eg: oolith, pisolith) Source: NADM SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:coated_particle
ControlledConcept.name: Coated particle

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A '...coated grain with a cortex of irregular, partially overlapping laminae. They are typically irregular in shape and may exhibit biogenic structures. Some forms lack a distinct nucleus. Oncoids are generally larger than 2 mm.' (Hallsworth and Knox, 1999, p. 27). Synonymous with oncolite: A small, variously shaped, concentrically laminated, calcareous sedimentary structure, resembling an oolith, and formed by the accretion of successive layer[s]... It...generally does not exceed 10 cm in dimension. (Jackson, 1997, p. 446). Source: Jackson 1997; Hallsworth and Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:oncoid
ControlledConcept.name: Oncoid

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A general, nongenetic term for a particle that resembles an oolith in outer appearance and size- (Jackson, 1997, p. 447). Hallsworth and Knox (1999, p. 27) describe ooids as coated grains that typically are spherical or ellipsoidal in shape, with the degree of roundness increasing outward. Concentric to semi-concentric coats are smoothly and evenly laminated. A nucleus usually is present, and may have a composition different from the coatings. Biogenic structures are not obvious. NADMSC SLTTs (2004) considers synomous with oolith. Source: Jackson1997; Hallsworth and Knox 1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:ooid
ControlledConcept.name: Ooid

ControlledConcept.gml:description: "A round or ellipsoidal accretionary body resembling a pea in size and shape.... A pisoid...is larger and less regular in form than an ooid, although it may have the same concentric and/or radial internal structure" (Jackson, 1997, p. 489). Source: NADM SLTTs 2004; Jackson 1997
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:pisoid
ControlledConcept.name: Pisoid

ControlledConcept.gml:description: a usually rounded aggregate of clay-sized calcareous (micritic) material; origin and size is not specified Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:peloid
ControlledConcept.name: Peloid

ControlledConcept.gml:description: an organic excrement, mainly of invertebrates, occuring especially in modern marine sediments but also fossilised in some sedimentary rocks, usually with simple ovoid form, less commonly rod-shaped. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:fecal_pellet
ControlledConcept.name: Fecal pellet

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A type of nonbiogenic particle formed by in situ or intrabasinal physical-chemical-mechanical processes without the direct biochemical activity of organisms, penecontemporaneously with sediment accumulation or during diagenetic modification. Source: NADM SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:syngenetic_particle
ControlledConcept.name: Syngenetic particle

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Fragments of extrusive igneous rock formed by mechanical friction of moving lava flow, breakage of chilled lava flow rinds, or gravity crumbling of active spines and domes. Gillespie and Styles (1999) include as type of juvenile pyroclastic fragment, inconsistent with definition of pyroclastic by IUGS and BGS. Source: Gillespie and Styles,1999
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:autoclast
ControlledConcept.name: Autoclast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Constituent that is the product of crystallization during formation of a compound Earth material (see NADMC1 2004). Serves to distinguish crystalline from granular rocks (Struik, 2002). Includes constituents crystallized in evaporite environments, during diagenesis or hydrothermal alteration, or in other low-temperature environments. Source: Struik, 2002; NADM SLTTs 2004
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:crystalline_grain
ControlledConcept.name: Crystalline grain

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Constitutent occurs as minute, spherical, rod, or hair-like forms. Typically appear isotropic in thin section. Source: Williams,Turner,Gilbert, 1954
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:crystallite
ControlledConcept.name: Crystallite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A crystalline grain in a metamorphic rock that is newly and completely formed during metamorphism Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:holoblast
ControlledConcept.name: Holoblast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Constituent occurs as minute incipient crystals that display some birefringence in thin section. Source: Williams,Turner,Gilbert, 1954
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:microlite
ControlledConcept.name: Microlite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A crystal or remnant of a crystal that is older than other mineral grains in the rock, especially in metamorphic rocks Source: Neuendorf et al. 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:paleoblast
ControlledConcept.name: Paleoblast

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Constituent particle that has the outward form of a mineral species or particle type, but the original minerals composing the particle have been altered or replaced by different minerals; a secondary mineral whose outward crystal form has been inherited from the orignal mineral it has replaced Source: Neuendorf et al. 2005; Spry 1969; Fettes and Desmons, 2007
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:pseudomorph
ControlledConcept.name: Pseudomorph

ControlledConcept.gml:description: a pseudomorph with the same composition as the original crystal (eg: calcite after aragonite) Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:paramorph
ControlledConcept.name: Paramorph

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A crystal that resembles a phenocryst in an igneous rock, but that is foreign to the rock in which it occurs Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:xenocryst
ControlledConcept.name: Xenocryst

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Generic term for a non-clastic particle that is itself composed of an aggregation of particles; Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:aggregate_non-clastic_particle
ControlledConcept.name: Aggregate non-clastic particle

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Elongate to irregular lense with radial aggregates of acicular and fibrous mineral coalescing along a central axis. Source: Williams,Turner,Gilbert 1954
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:axiolite
ControlledConcept.name: Axiolite

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A hard, compact mass or aggregate of mineral matter, normally subsperical but commonly oblate, disc-shaped or irregular. Formed by precipitation of mineral from solution in the pores of a granular rock, localized around a nucleus or center, to define a discrete, sharply separated object. Size ranges from cm to meters. Particle geometry description for concretion describes the concretion size and shape, not the size and shape of particles forming the concretion. Source: Neuendorf et al, 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:concretionary_particle
ControlledConcept.name: Concretionary particle

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Aggregate non-clastic particle that are of igneous origin. Particle types for compound material are restricted to inclusions that are typically of a size consistent with hand-sample description to characterize a kind of rock or a rock sample; larger inclusion types are included in the GeologicUnitPart role vocabulary. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:igneous_inclusion
ControlledConcept.name: Igneous inclusion

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An aggregate of crystals of the same mineral Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:glomerocryst
ControlledConcept.name: Glomerocryst

ControlledConcept.gml:description: igneous constituent typically mafic, equant rounded spheroid with concentric mineralogic banding Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:orb
ControlledConcept.name: Orb

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Lens-shaped bodies, usually mm to cm thick, and centimeters to 1-2 decimeters long, typically seen on surfaces of some pyroclastic rocks. The name fiamme comes from the Italian word for flames, describing their shape. The term is descriptive and non-genetic.Generally interpreted to form by the collapse of pumice fragments during welding in a hot pyroclastic deposit. Source: Neuendorf et al 2005; http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fiamme
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:fiamme
ControlledConcept.name: Fiamme

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An irregularly rounded mass of a mineral or mineral aggregate normally having a warty or knobby surface and no internal sructure, usually with a contrasting composition from the enclosing sediment or rock matrix in which it is embedded, and that can be separated as a discrete mass from the host material. Igneous nodules should be classified as 'Igneous inclusions'. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:nodule
ControlledConcept.name: Nodule

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Particle formed by chemical precipitation at sediment-water interface, lacking layered structure that characterizes coated grains. Includes glauconite grains, manganese nodules, phosphate grains. Manganese nodule--"An irregular, black to brown, friable, Source: NADM SLTTs 2004; Jackson 1997
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:syngenetic_nodule
ControlledConcept.name: Syngenetic nodule

ControlledConcept.gml:description: a tabular body, generally a few cm to a few metres long, within a plutonic rock, having different mineral proportions and colour to the surrounding rock Source: GGIPAC
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:schlieren
ControlledConcept.name: Schlieren

ControlledConcept.gml:description: a rounded or spherical mass of acicular or fibrous mineral, generally in glassy siliceous lava. Source: Williams,Turner,Gilbert 1954
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:spherule
ControlledConcept.name: Spherule

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Spherulitic cluster of crystals in mafic rock, usually consists of divergent plagioclase fibers, with or without interstitial glass, or intergrown with granules of pyroxene, olivine or iron ore. (equivalent to Spherule, but in mafic rock) Source: Williams,Turner,Gilbert 1954
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:variole
ControlledConcept.name: Variole

ControlledConcept.gml:description: a tabular or sheet-like part of a compound material, genetic origin not specified Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:intrusive_sheet
ControlledConcept.name: Intrusive sheet

ControlledConcept.gml:description: a tabular or sheet-like part of a compound material formed by hydrothermal (or other metasomatic) mineral filling a fracture; may be associated with replacement of the host rock adjacent to the body Source: Neuendorf et al 2005; this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:hydrothermal_vein
ControlledConcept.name: Hydrothermal vein

ControlledConcept.gml:description: a tabular or sheet like part of a compound material formed by the intrusion of magma Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:igneous_vein
ControlledConcept.name: Igneous vein

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Generic term for a small rounded particle of uncertain origin Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:bleb
ControlledConcept.name: Bleb

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Constituent is empty space between particles in a compound material; generally filled with some sort of fluid. Cavity particle types can be used to describe porosity in a granular material. Source: this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:cavity
ControlledConcept.name: Cavity

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Cavity filled with secondary minerals; denotes that cavities are filled vesicles, thus restricted to volcanic rock. Source: Neuendorf et al 2005; SMR
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:amygdule
ControlledConcept.name: Amygdule

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Primary or penecontemporaneous gap or cavity in the framework of a sedimentary rock, larger than grain-supported intersticies. May be open space or have partial to complete fill with secondary cement or introduced sediment. Source: Neuendorf et al 2005; SMR
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:fenestra
ControlledConcept.name: Fenestra

ControlledConcept.gml:description: A cavity within a crystal containing liquid and/or gas, formed by the entrapment in crystal irregularities of fluid, commonly that from which the mineral crystallised. Source: Neuendorf et al., 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:fluid_inclusion
ControlledConcept.name: Fluid inclusion

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Bubble-like cavity with concentric shells of finely crystalline minerals; open space remains in core of structure. Radiating fibrous structure may be present in secondary mineral fill. Typically in silicic volcanic rock. Source: Neuendorf et al 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:lithophysae
ControlledConcept.name: Lithophysae

ControlledConcept.gml:description: An irregular cavity in a phaneritic igneous rock into which small crystals of the rock-forming minerals protrude. Source: Neuendorf et al 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:miarolitic_cavity
ControlledConcept.name: Miarolitic cavity

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Cavity in volcanic rock formed by trapped gas. Use amygdule if filled with secondary mineral. Source: Neuendorf et al 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:vesicle
ControlledConcept.name: Vesicle

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Irregular cavity in rock; generic term with no connotation of origin of cavity. May be lined with crystals of different mineral compostion to the host rock Source: Neuendorf et al 2005
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:vug
ControlledConcept.name: Vug

ControlledConcept.gml:description: Open space between particles in a granular aggregate Source: Neuendorf et al 2005, this vocabulary
ControlledConcept.gml:name: urn:cgi:classifier:CGI:ParticleType:200811:pore_space
ControlledConcept.name: Pore space
